content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fine puzzle for simulation and using BFS with priority queue

As with another puzzle of the author, the  definition of  l and w is contrary to what is usual at CG  puzzles.
At first I thought the order in the input statement was wrong, but it it is not, they are defined same way as they are used.
Otherwise the puzzle is fine, I solved it and ready to approve before it expires.
But I suspect many solvers would  mix-up l and w because of conventions resulting unnecessary debugging, so if the author wishes to change this, that would be better. If not, I will approve it within 5 days (not today as I would be the 3rd resulting immediate publication).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: this delightful problem exudes elegance and intellectual charm, making it a most welcome addition to any discerning solver's repertoire.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This one was really fun! I used a stack instead of a priority queue, so it uses DFS. I think the way my beam traverses the room is very clever.

Output
* Please add "(column, row)" after "coordinates".

Constraints
* Please change 20 to 10.

* Please delete the second constraint.

* Please add:
1 ≤ Number of mirrors ≤ 16
The laser will always be able to reach the target after flipping at least one mirror.

Stub generator
* …

Cases
* Please swap "Multiple" test and validator. This ensures that at least one visible test has l < w and at least one validator has l > w.

* Please add a pair of cases where certain mirror combinations could lead to an infinite loop (assuming the beam can pass through the laser itself), e.g.

7 5
./...\\
./...\.
.......
.\.L./.
...T..\
W

Thanks.
Should I add stack and DFS as tags?
I think length as the horizontal and width as the vertical in a 2D grid.

OK, I approve it as is. Maybe I am the only one with this. 
If not, you will see it in puzzle comments by others.
When I look at other 2D puzzles, it is the same as me, so I think it is what you think.
I also think it's better to swap "l" and "w", though it's not a big deal to me if they aren't swapped.

nope, believe me, I solved 900+ puzzles on CG, the convention is that width goes along the input string in a grid (that is x) and l goes down, so the number of strings of the grid (that is y).
Does not matter, I approved already, the puzzle is published
Maybe DFS which implies the use of a stack?

Constraints
* Second constraint: Please add "1 ≤".

* Please add:
The laser will always be able to reach the target after flipping at least one mirror.

Cases
* Please add a pair of cases where all of the following hold:
  • The beam must pass through the laser itself (see also final point below).
  • There are 16 mirrors.
  • All mirrors are initially set the same way (/ or \),
  • Walls are used to block alternative minimum-flip paths.
Example:
7 10
/../...
..././.
.......
...L./.
.....#.
./././/
...T./#
.....//
./.../.
/./....
E

Goal
* Please add "The beam can pass through the laser."

* Alternatively, if this behaviour is not desired, explicitly state "The beam cannot pass through the laser", and provide corresponding test cases.

Thanks.

Goal
* Please move this line:
"The beam can pass through the laser."
to below this line:
"- \ turns N ↔ W and S ↔ E"

Cases
* "Confusing.1" (validator): There seem to be two possible ways to flip 4 mirrors. Please check.

Thanks.

Let's distinguish between the laser (the device or source) and the beam (the ray of light). Please change the following:

   (Goal section)
   • blocks laser => blocks beam
   
   • laser hits a mirror => beam hits a mirror
   
   (Constraints section)
   • The laser => The beam

No further comments for the time being once these edits are made.

Thanks.
